utterances: NPR's Karen Grigsby Bates reports.
New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson could have made the announcement that he was jumping into the presidential race from home.
He didn't.
I want to thank all of you for joining us here today.
It means so much to me to announce my candidacy in California, the state that I was born and where I'm going to win this primary here in the state.
(Soundbite of applause)
Richardson came to California last week for sentimental reasons, sure.
But as the only Latino presidential candidate, he also came to touch base with the state's rich trove of Latino voters.
Powerful L.A.
County supervisor Gloria Molina introduced Richardson to the crowd during his visit.
She's been working hard to persuade her charismatic mayor, Antonio Villaraigosa, to spend time with her candidate.
I think he's going to be doing a public event with him soon, even though he probably will not be endorsing any candidate for a while, but I'm not sure.
Well, Villaraigosa did make an endorsement soon after.
Hillary Clinton has the strength, the experience, a record of proven results.
She's the one candidate who has been there, and she has my vote for president of the United States of America.
(Soundbite of applause)
Obviously, that wasn't the endorsement Molina was hoping he'd make.
Marcelo Gaete is program director of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials, or NALEO.
He says Villaraigosa's endorsement of Clinton wasn't so much a diss of Richardson as a nod to pragmatism.
I think that Hispanic leadership has demonstrated time and time again that when they make decisions, they make it based on their constituents, themselves, and the political realities of the time.
The political reality of this moment has Clinton running in first place and Richardson in fourth.
Backing the right horse in this race can place Villaraigosa and Los Angeles on the front burner of the politician beholden to the votes the mayor can deliver.
Gregory Rodriguez is the guy from the New American Foundation you heard in Mike Pesca's piece a moment ago.
He says most people can see that pretty clearly, especially Mexican-American politicians.
Many of them have been political players in Southern California for years.
Rodriguez says they know how the game is played.
I don't really believe there will be a great deal of pressure from any - any Mexican-American politician's constituencies to endorse Bill Richardson for president.
Villaraigosa didn't run away from his ethnicity when he campaigned to become L.A.'s first Latino mayor in over 130 years.
But once elected, he made it clear he would be mayor of all of Los Angeles.

NALEO's Marcelo Gaete says earlier political models merely required white politicians to secure photo-ops with the ethnics they were wooing, and maybe find room for a token somewhere in their administration.
Gaete says those days are over.
They have to pay attention not only to the diverse leadership but the diverse electorate.
Running for president in 2008 is a lot different than running for president at the turn of the last century.
That something that will be increasingly apparent as all presidential candidates continue to woo ethnic voters and officials in this most diverse state.
Karen Grigsby Bates, NPR News.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Rachel Martin.
There are new signs today that the Syrian crisis is spilling beyond Syria's borders.
This morning, two rockets slammed into Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, injuring several people.
That came just hours after Hezbollah's leader vowed support of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.
NPR's Peter Kenyon joins us from Istanbul, where he is following a meeting of Syrian opposition figures.
Peter, it seems that the Syrian opposition remains plagued by outside pressures, a lot of internal disputes, while the violence in and around Syria just keep getting worse.
I mean, we hear that fierce fighting continues in the area of Qusair in Homs province today.
What do we know about this rocket attack?
Well, this rocket attack could be a significant development.
The south Beirut neighborhood over in Lebanon where they exploded has long been known as Hezbollah territory.

Some people are seeing this as a response to last night's speech by Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah, who announced a new phase of what he calls the resistance, which has always been against Israel in the past.
Now, he's promising an all-out fight to support the regime of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, who is a long-time Hezbollah patron.
The source of the rockets appears to be in a hilly area southeast of Beirut.
There's been no claim of responsibility so far.
For the residents of Lebanon, where memories of their own bloody 15-year civil war are never far from the surface, this is bound to be a worrying sign.
In North Lebanon, sectarian fighting's going on in Tripoli.
The border area is very tense.
The tide of violence is rising, it's spreading, and no one seems sure how to proceed.
You're following an important meeting in Istanbul.
It's a meeting that's supposed to answer the question of whether the Syrian opposition will take part in talks with the government, talks that Washington and Moscow are trying to arrange next month.
How does that look?
I would say the opposition skepticism remains very deeply entrenched but the pressure to attend is increasing.
Coalition members that I've spoken with say the government can't be trusted.
They've shown no sign of changing and the demand is still that Assad must agree to leave power before talks can really start on a transition government.
Now that's a non-starter for the regime, of course, so the diplomats are going to have to get pretty creative.
